intro: Fimbristylis nutans var. typica, commonly known as the drooping hairgrass, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It is a member of the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, and typically grows in wet or moist environments such as marshes and roadside ditches. The plant features slender, grass-like leaves and produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, wind-pollinated flowers. It is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in both full sun and partial shade. Its delicate appearance makes it a common ornamental plant in gardens and landscapes.
